results.title: John Krasinski and the Tense Wait for ‘A Quiet Place Part II’
results.abstract: It’s been more than a year since the film he wrote and directed was originally set for release. Now, as the sequel to the 2018 hit reaches theaters, Hollywood is holding its breath.

multimedia.caption: Blunt, Simmonds and Krasinski, who said that as he waited for the film to come out, he spent the past year hovering “somewhere between optimism and naïveté.”
multimedia.copyright: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times

results.title: Binge-Viewing Movies? Netflix Bets on the ‘Fear Street’ Trilogy.
results.abstract: The streamer hopes that by turning adaptations of the R.L. Stine series into weekly film events, audiences will stay glued to the screen.

results.title: How a Review Changed Both Sarah Silverman and Our Critic
results.abstract: A.O. Scott critiqued her approach to comedy in a 2005 movie. Now they sit down to talk about what he got right and wrong, and why owning up to mistakes is freeing.

multimedia.caption: Silverman said, “I never wrote stand-up by topic or by what’s taboo. I know it seems like I do, but I just don’t. That’s never been my process.”
multimedia.copyright: Photo Illustration by Chase Middleton for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Shrek’ at 20: How a Chaotic Project Became a Beloved Hit
results.abstract: Expectations were so low and the hurdles so plentiful that the crew wasn’t eager to work on the movie. Recasting after the death of Chris Farley added challenges, too.

multimedia.caption: Fiona (Cameron Diaz) and Shrek (Mike Myers) in the film that started it all.

results.title: MGM Looks to Amazon as the Hollywood Studio Tries to Find a Buyer
results.abstract: A deal would add Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer’s 4,000 films to Amazon’s streaming library, including the James Bond, Rocky and “Legally Blonde” franchises.

multimedia.caption: The 58-year-old James Bond franchise, which MGM owns 50 percent of, is a Hollywood crown jewel that has generated tens of billions of dollars in ticket sales.

results.title: What I Learned About Democracy From the Movies
results.abstract: Seven films that paint a portrait of America in all its contradictions, inconsistencies and outright delusions.

results.title: Charles Grodin, Star of ‘Beethoven’ and ‘Heartbreak Kid,’ Dies at 86
results.abstract: A familiar face who was especially adept at deadpan comedy, he also appeared on Broadway in “Same Time, Next Year,” wrote books and had his own talk show.

multimedia.caption: The actor Charles Grodin with the title dog in the hit 1992 family movie “Beethoven.” “I don’t complain,” he said, “when the editor chooses my worst take because it’s the dog’s best take.”

results.title: ‘It’s Magic What We Do.’ Movie Theaters Get Starry-Eyed Once More.
results.abstract: The industry was decimated by the pandemic, with theaters shut across the country and new films delayed by Hollywood studios. But now cinemas are ready to fill up their seats again. Will audiences follow?

multimedia.caption: The Alamo Drafthouse theater chain declared bankruptcy during the pandemic, though it’s hopeful about the future.

results.title: Dr. Aaron Stern, Who Enforced the Movie Ratings Code, Dies at 96
results.abstract: He was a New York psychiatrist who went to Hollywood to help lay down guidelines for sex and violence in films. Not everyone was pleased.

multimedia.caption: The psychiatrist Dr. Aaron Stern with his wife, Betty Lee, in 2019. He wielded considerable power in the early 1970s when he was head of Hollywood’s movie rating board.
The psychiatrist Dr. Aaron Stern with his wife, Betty Lee, in 2019. He wielded considerable power in the early 1970s when he was head of Hollywood’s movie rating board.

results.title: Stereotypes Are Rife Among Asian and Pacific Islander Film Roles, Study Finds
results.abstract: Two-thirds of characters reflect stereotypes, and just 3.4 percent of movies had leads or coleads who were Asians or Pacific Islanders, the study of 1,300 movies found.

multimedia.caption: Constance Wu, whose leading role in the movie “Hustlers” (2019) was praised as a good character in a new study. Not many Asians or Pacific Islanders star in movies, the study found.

results.title: Behind Every Hero or Villain, There Is Tech Support
results.abstract: Cutting-edge technology is often used in comics by the able assistants who fall under the trope “the guy in the chair.” But they are not always men and are not always helping the hero.

multimedia.caption: Noah Kuttler, a DC villain known as the Calculator, is a classic example of the comic book trope known as “the guy in the chair.”

results.title: A Titan Ascends in Media World’s Game of Thrones
results.abstract: Jason Kilar was named chief executive of WarnerMedia just last year, but now he is negotiating his departure after being sidelined by David Zaslav, the longtime leader of Discovery.

results.title: A Kevin Spacey Accuser Tried to Sue Anonymously. A Judge Said No.
results.abstract: As sexual assault cases proliferate, judges must weigh accusers’ requests for anonymity against the tradition of open courts and fairness toward defendants.

multimedia.caption: Kevin Spacey attends a 2019 hearing in Nantucket, Mass. Prosecutors dropped a criminal case against Mr. Spacey where it was alleged he groped an 18-year-old man at a Nantucket bar in 2016. It is just one of a series of sexual misconduct allegations against the actor in recent years.
